Night Shift slides off the Stegasaurouses back as he looks back to him in a=
 confused manner.  Rat Trap does the same.

" Sorry big guy, but this is wh=
ere we gotta get off.  Thanks for the lift though, saved us some gas and ti=
me."

Rat Trap sniffles.

"I'm sure gonna miss this big guy.  No telln' if =
we'll ever meet up with 'em again."

The large dino looks down to both of t=
hem, nudges them gently with his snout, and then continues on his own path.=
  Night Shift cautiously scans the area, as he tries to get his GPS back on=
line.  Yet he motions Rat Trap to stay close to him, as he watches the larg=
er predators all around him.

" Stay close Rat Trap.  We're in uncharted te=
rritory now. The ground's very uneven here, doubt that my alt form is gonna=
 do us any good.  I could travel for a while like that but if I blow more t=
han just one tire, we're sunk."

Rat Trap nodds.

"Better save it, and stic=
k ta walking.  And why didn't ya think of loadn' up on spares anyway?!"

Ni=
ght Shift looks back to him.

" The Ark only carried so many spare tires fo=
r my make'n model.  Yeah, the speedsters had plenty of spares but the bigge=
r vehicles, they're hard ta find."

Rat Trap sighs.

"Oh, so I take it they=
 all got used up."

Night Shift nodds.

"Yep, between Tucson, me, and a cou=
ple others, we used 'em up because we're off road vehicles. C'mon, I got th=
e signal, and I think I know where we're headed."

They begin another trek =
toward the Black Fortresses former location.

" I hope Cheetor's still in o=
ne piece."

--- In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com, Super Cyclonus <supercyclonus@..=
.> wrote:
>
> The trip via dinosaur does indeed make the trip faster than i=
t ordinarily
> would have been. Not because they are necessarily faster ove=
rall, since they
> were definitely slow movers, but in this rough and uneve=
n terrain they made
> better speed then either of the two Maximals could ha=
ve. Also most predators
> give these large Stegosauruses a wide berth!
> 
>=
 However one disadavantage of being so large is the almost constant need to=

> feed, which the creatures do as they walk. Their large frames knocking o=
ver
> small trees or propping up on the larger ones. What this means for th=
e
> Maximals is that their path to the Predacon base is not going to be a
>=
 straight one as the dinos detour to grab morsels of food, quench thier
> t=
hirst or investigate an interesting smell along the way.
> 
> In the distan=
ce the Maximals can hear the sounds of other large creatures,
> some of the=
m the dinosaurs, but others are from the larger mammals that have
> appeare=
d - saber toothed cats and other larger and deadly predators.
> 
> As time =
passes the Maximals' internal compasses began to chirp in alarm as
> the cr=
eatures they were riding are began to veer off the course. They were
> trav=
elling more south than the east they needed to go.
> 
> As more time passed=
 they came to what looked to have been an old river bed,
> and in the dista=
nce a heard of Stegosaurus were walking, or should we so
> plodding, their =
trip taking them to the south, evidently on some migratory
> trail. They we=
re no longer going in the direction that the Maximals needed
> to be travel=
ling. However one good thing was that they were no in more open
> country, =
the large plains beckoned before them. The Maximals had many more
> miles t=
o travel before they arrived at their destination, but at least they
> coul=
d see where they were going . . . but then again that means that any
> pred=
ators could see them coming as well.
> 
> (TAG)
>

e time lines wouldn't really match up and it wouldnt
